data.title: Bach, Handel and Scarlatti... interesting discovery
data.text:
When I play in my PC a Naxos CD of Domenico Scarlatti's keyboard sonatas

(Balázs Szokolay / piano, highly recommended), my Real Player provides the

following interesting piece of information:

Scarlatti was born on the same day as both Handel and Bach (26 October

1685).

Many music and history books will need to be rewritten to reflect this

amazing fact.

Jaime Jean

Mexico City



Perhaps the folks at the JSB newsgroup would enlighten you as to his

actual birthday? (I don't think I know Handel's -- radio stations don't

tend to dedicate marathons to him.)

--

Peter T. Daniels gram...@att.net

In article <40FEBC...@worldnet.att.net>,



I don't know if this chestnut is true, but I had heard of the

triple birthday story before.

--

Matthew H. Fields http://personal.www.umich.edu/~fields

Music: Splendor in Sound

"Hey, don't knock Placebo, its the only thing effective for my hypochondria."

Brights have a naturalistic world-view. http://www.the-brights.net/

> In article <40FEBC...@worldnet.att.net>,

> Peter T. Daniels <gram...@worldnet.att.net> wrote:

>

>>Jaime Jean wrote:

>>

>>>When I play in my PC a Naxos CD of Domenico Scarlatti's keyboard sonatas

>>>(Balázs Szokolay / piano, highly recommended), my Real Player provides the

>>--

>

>

> I don't know if this chestnut is true, but I had heard of the

> triple birthday story before.

>

>

Ya know, Darwin was born on the same day as Abraham Lincoln. ooooh,

spooky!

Steve





Now, there's one on me--I'd never heard of Erasmus, much less his

involvement in the development of species.

What I don't learn here--

Yes, it was Charles--born, IIRC on Feb 12, 1809.

Steve

> >

> >> Michael Haslam wrote:

> >>

> >>> Mark & Steven Bornfeld DDS <bornfe...@dentaltwins.com> wrote:

> >>>

> >>>> Ya know, Darwin was born on the same day as Abraham Lincoln.

> >>>> ooooh, spooky!

> >>>

> >>> Charles or Erasmus?

> >> Now I've gotta google Erasmus Darwin--durn.

> >

> >

> > Now, there's one on me--I'd never heard of Erasmus, much less his

> >involvement in the development of species. What I don't learn here-- > >

> > Yes, it was Charles--born, IIRC on Feb 12, 1809.

> >

> >Steve

>

> What was the connection with Josiah Wedgewood?

Were they both members of the Lunatic Society (so named as they met on

evenings with full moons to enable easier journeys home)? I've got to

look this up now. Durn. And I have at least two connections; a Godson

who's a descendent of Darwin (and Keynes) and a great great uncle who

owned a house formerly owned by Erasmus Darwin.

MJHaslam

In article <1ghbes2.1ug4brm1m0ixh5N%innat...@btinternet.com>,

innat...@btinternet.com (Michael Haslam) wrote:

> Dr.Matt <fie...@mspacman.gpcc.itd.umich.edu> wrote:

(snip)

> > What was the connection with Josiah Wedgewood?

>

> Were they both members of the Lunatic Society (so named as they met on

> evenings with full moons to enable easier journeys home)? I've got to

> look this up now. Durn. And I have at least two connections; a Godson

> who's a descendent of Darwin (and Keynes) and a great great uncle who

> owned a house formerly owned by Erasmus Darwin.

>

> MJHaslam

>

More correctly named the 'Lunar Society', though they referred to

themselves as lunatics, since they chose days when there was a full moon

at night, so that there would be good illumination for the night-time ride

home after a good dinner.

There's an excellent book - "The Lunar Men" by Jenny Uglow - which

recounts the history of an amazing group who played a disproportionate

role in the Industrial Revolution in England. Erasmus Darwin (grandfather

of Charles) and Josiah Wedgewood were just two of them.

David Foster

"M.D. Foster" <m.davi...@virgin.net> wrote in message

news:memo.2004072...@mdfoster.compulink.co.uk...

> In article <1ghbes2.1ug4brm1m0ixh5N%innat...@btinternet.com>,

> innat...@btinternet.com (Michael Haslam) wrote:

>

> > Dr.Matt <fie...@mspacman.gpcc.itd.umich.edu> wrote:

> (snip)

> > > What was the connection with Josiah Wedgewood?

> >

> > Were they both members of the Lunatic Society (so named as they met on

> > evenings with full moons to enable easier journeys home)? I've got to

> > look this up now. Durn. And I have at least two connections; a Godson

> > who's a descendent of Darwin (and Keynes) and a great great uncle who

> > owned a house formerly owned by Erasmus Darwin.

> >

> > MJHaslam

> >

>

> More correctly named the 'Lunar Society', though they referred to

> themselves as lunatics, since they chose days when there was a full moon

> at night, so that there would be good illumination for the night-time ride

> home after a good dinner.

>

But didn't most people - of that social class, of course - organize their

evening events on that basis?

Moonlight was very important in a civilization without outdoor artificial

lighting. Household almenachs ghave the phases of the moon.

And 18th-century households usually had at least one clock showing the

phases of the moon.

--

Keith Edgerley
